results.title: Earnings in conflict
results.brief_description: A proposal by Lord Wilfred Brown to combat the wages inflation in Great Britain. The narrative is set in the future, at a time when such a system has been adopted. An American TV interviewer is the linkman, making an enquiry into the “revolutionary” British procedure.

results.title: Early trick films [1898-1912]
results.brief_description: Compilation including “The House that Jack built” (dir. G.A. Smith); “Upside down or the human flies” (dir. R.W. Paul); “The Brahmin and the butterfly” (dir. Georges Melies); “The Motorist” (dir. R.W. Paul); “The Magic screen”; “Dante’s inferno”; and in its entirety, “The Invisible thief”.

results.title: Early stone tools
results.creator_credit: Extension Media Center, University of California and Clyde B Smith
results.brief_description: Traces the development of stone tools and parallels their development with the evolution of man from austropithecus to homo sapiens. Demonstrates percussion flaking techniques to produce a variety of tools. Shows actual prehistoric tools.

results.title: Early sound films
results.brief_description: Short extracts from the following early sound films which were milestones in the history of Cinema: ‘The Jazz Singer’, ‘The Lights of New York’, ‘On With The Show’, ‘Show of Shows’, ‘In Old Arizona’, ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’.

results.title: Early social behaviour
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Yale Clinic of Child Development and Arnold Gesell
results.brief_description: Shows the manifestation of the infant personality in a variety of social settings. Ten different children from 8 weeks to 7 years of age are studied and individual differences are emphasised. Also the social significance of the household is conveyed by scenes that reflect parent-child relationships.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Yale Clinic of Child Development and Arnold Gesell

results.title: Early Russian cinema. Vol 7: Evgenii Bauer
results.creator_credit: A Khanzhonov and Co and Evegnii Bauer
results.brief_description: Three short silent films by Soviet director Evegnii Bauer that explore themes of class, sexual politics, doomed love, grief and sanity. “A child of the big city” Mary, a seamstress with a meagre existence who dreams of a grander life of luxury and wealth, meets Victor, a well-do-do young man, who spurns his pretentious peers. Beguiled by the luxuries that pepper Victor’s world, Mary becomes flirtatious and develops a taste for decadent habits. Financially ruined and personally demoralised, Victor despairs at Mary’s transformation. This mournful, melancholy melodrama, and morality play, examines the notions of class and corrupting influence of money on character. “The 1102nd ruse” An elderly husband believes himself inured to the skilful wiles of women, to the frustration of his scheming wife. But she is determined to hoodwink him by inventing a cunning ruse unfamiliar to him. A slight comedy of manners that comments on the power of sexuality whilst gently mocking the sanctity of marriage. “Daydreams” A man, mourning the death of his wife, is soon romancing an actress who shares a likeness with his deceased beloved. As his obsession grows, he fears insanity and is beset by ghostly apparitions. All feature musical score, Russian intertitles and English subtitles.
